abstract.para: This document is the complete user guide of VLC .

sect2.title: Overview
sect2.para: VideoLAN is a complete software solution for video streaming, developed by students of the Ecole Centrale Paris and developers from all over the world, under the GNU General Public License (GPL). VideoLAN is designed to stream MPEG videos on high bandwidth networks.
The VideoLAN solution includes :

listitem.para: VLS (VideoLAN Server), which can stream MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 files, DVDs, digital satellite channels, digital terrestial television channels and live videos on the network in unicast or multicast,

VLC (initially VideoLAN Client), which can be used as a server to stream MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 files, DVDs and live videos on the network in unicast or multicast ; or used as a client to receive, decode and display MPEG streams under multiple operating systems.

sect2.para: Here is an illustration of the complete VideoLAN solution :

figure.title: Global VideoLAN solution La solution VideoLAN globale

sect2.para: More details about the project can be found on the VideoLAN Web site.

simplesect.title: VLC
simplesect.para: VLC works on many platforms : Linux, Windows, Mac OS X, BeOS, *BSD, Solaris, Familiar Linux, Yopy/Linupy and QNX. It can read :

listitem.para: MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 / DivX files from a hard disk, a CD-ROM drive, ...
DVDs and VCDs,
from a satellite card (DVB-S),
MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 streams from the network sent by VLS or VLC's stream output.

simplesect.para: VLC can also be used as a server to stream :

listitem.para: MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 / DivX files,
DVDs,
from an MPEG encoding card,

simplesect.para: to :

listitem.para: one machine (i.e. to one IP address) : this is called unicast,
a dynamic group of machines that the clients can join or leave (i.e. to a multicast IP address) : this is called multicast,

simplesect.para: in IPv4 or IPv6 .
To get the complete list of VLC's possibilities on each plateform supported, see the VLC features page.

note.para: VLC doesn't work on Mac OS 9, and will probably never do.

simplesect.title: VLS
simplesect.para: VLS can stream :

listitem.para: an MPEG-1, MPEG-2 or MPEG-4 files stored on a hard drive or on a CD,
a DVD located in a local DVD drive or copied on a hard disk,

a satellite card (DVB-S) or a digital terrestial television card (DVB-T)
,

an MPEG encoding card
;

simplesect.para: to:

listitem.para: one machine (i.e. to one IP address) : this is called unicast,
a dynamic group of machines that the clients can join or leave (i.e. to a multicast IP address) : this is called multicast,

simplesect.para: in IPv4 or IPv6 .

A Pentium 100 MHz with 32 MB of memory should be enough to send one stream on the network. When streaming a lot of videos stored on a hard drive, the actual limitation is not the processor but the hard drive and the network connection.
VLS works under Linux and Windows. To get the complete list of VLS's possibilities on each plateform supported, see the streaming features page.

simplesect.title: Mini-SAP-server
simplesect.para: You can add a channel information service based on the SAP/SDP standard to the VideoLAN solution. The mini-SAP-server sends announces about the multicast programs on the network in IPv4 or IPv6, and VLCs receive these annouces and automatically add the programs announced to their playlist.
The mini-SAP-server works under Linux and Mac OS X.

sect1.title: What is a codec ?
sect1.para: To fully understand the VideoLAN solution, you must understand the difference between a codec and a container format

listitem.para: A codec is a compression algorithm, used to reduce the size of a stream. There are audio codecs and video codecs. MPEG-1, MPEG-2, MPEG-4, Vorbis, DivX, ... are codecs

A container format contains one or several streams already encoded by codecs. Very often, there is an audio stream and a video one. AVI, Ogg, MOV, ASF, ... are container formats. The streams contained can be encoded using different codecs. In a perfect world, you could put any codec in any container format. Unfortunately, there are some incompatibilities. You can find a matrix of possible codecs and container formats on the features page

sect1.para:
To decode a stream, VLC first demuxes it. This means that it reads the container format and separates audio, video, and subtitles, if any. Then, each of these are passed decoders that do the mathematical processing to decompress the streams
.
There is a particular thing about MPEG:

listitem.para: MPEG is a codec. There are several versions of it, called MPEG-1, MPEG-2, MPEG-4, ...
MPEG is also a container format, sometimes refered to as MPEG System. There are several types of MPEG: ES, PS, and TS

When you play an MPEG video from a DVD, for instance, the MPEG stream is actually composed of several streams (called Elementary Streams, ES): there is one stream for video, one for audio, another for subtitles, and so on. These different streams are mixed together into a single Program Stream (PS). So, the .VOB files you can find in a DVD are actually MPEG-PS files. But this PS format is not adapted for streaming video through a network or by satellite, for instance. So, another format called Transport Stream (TS) was designed for streaming MPEG videos through such channels.

sect2.title: Documentation
sect2.para: The user documentation of VideoLAN is made up of 4 documents :

listitem.para: the VideoLAN Quickstart. This document will give you a quick overview of of VLC, VLC's stream output, the Video On Demand solution and the channel information service system.
the VideoLAN HOWTO. This document is the complete guide of the VideoLAN streaming solution.
the VLC user guide. This document is the complete guide for VLC.
the VLS user guide. This document is the complete guide for VLS.
the VideoLAN FAQ. This document contains Frequently Asked Questions about VideoLAN.

sect2.para:
The latest version of these documents can be found on the documentation page
.

You can also have a look at the VideoLAN Wiki. This is a website that everyone can change. We use it to document everything that is not in the "official" documentation: the tips and tricks for each O.S., the graphical interfaces, etc...

sect2.title: User support
sect2.para: If you have problems using VideoLAN, and if you don't find the answer to your problems in the documentation, please look at the online archive of the mailing-lists. There are two English-speaking mailing-lists for the users :

listitem.para:
vlc@videolan.org for the questions on VLC
,

streaming@videolan.org for the questions on VLS, mini-SAP-server and the network
.

sect2.para: If you want to subscribe or unsubscribe to the mailing-lists, please go to the mailing-list page.

You can also talk with VideoLAN users and developers on IRC : server irc.freenode.net, channel #videolan
.

If you find a bug, please follow the instructions on the bug reporting page
.

For a complete list of all VLC modules, please have a look at the LIST file in the subdirectory "modules" of the VLC source tree.
If you installed VLC through a binary file, you will get the default modules. If, however, you want to customize VLC to your needs, you will have to compile VLC from sources.
If you don't intend to compile VLC and want only the regular functions, reading this part is not very useful.

sect1.title: Video outputs
sect1.para: Video outputs are the modules that enable the support of some systems to display the video on your screen.

sect2.title: x11

para.emphasis: For Unix with X11 servers only

sect2.para: This is the basic x11 video output. It only requires a working X11 server. You will need xlibs headers to compile it (xlibs-dev package on Debian systems).

sect2.title: xvideo
sect2.para: It requires an xvideo compliant graphic card (it is the case for nearly all modern cards). It uses hardware acceleration for YUV transformation and rescaling.

sect2.title: sdl
sect2.para: This video output uses sdl libraries. You need at least version 1.1.6 of this libraries.
You may indicate the path to the sdl-config program with the --with-sdl-config-path=PATH switch, when running the configre script.

sect2.title: directx
sect2.para: This video output uses Microsoft Direct X libraries. It is recommended for the win32 port.
You may indicate the path to directX libraries and headers with the --with-directx=PATH switch, when running the configure script.

sect2.title: wingdi
sect2.para: This video output uses GDI. It is designed for users who don't have Direct X, but the perfs are very low. If you have DirectX, do not use it.

sect2.title: fb
sect2.para: This is the frame buffer video output. It requires that your kernel was compiled with frame buffer support.

sect2.title: glide
sect2.para: This video output uses Glide libraries (hardware acceleration for 3Dfx cards).
You may indicate the path to the library with the --with-glide=PATH configure option.

sect2.title: mga
sect2.para: This module provides hardware acceleration for Matrox cards under GNU/Linux.

sect2.title: aa
sect2.para: This is the ASCII Art Video Output. This video output uses the aalib library to display video through ASCII art. It requires aalib headers (aalib1-dev package under Debian GNU/Linux) to compile.

sect2.title: svgalib
sect2.para: This is a video output for the SVGAlib library.

sect2.title: qte
sect2.para:
This is a video output for QT Embedded, an iPaq-specifiq graphical library
.

sect1.title: Video filters modules
sect1.para:
These modules allow you to perform modifications on the rendered image
.

sect2.title: deinterlace
sect2.para:
This filter deinterlaces video. It is useful with streams coming from a digital satellite channel or digital terrestial television channels
.

sect2.title: wall
sect2.para: This filter allows you to have the video cut in pieces in several windows, which you can order as you wish. It can be used to generate image walls with several sources.

sect2.title: distort
sect2.para: This filter adds a distortion effect to the video. Who said it was useless ? :-)

sect2.title: transform
sect2.para: This filter allows to rotate the video in several ways .

sect2.title: invert
sect2.para: This filter inverses colors.

sect2.title: adjust
sect2.para: This filter allows you to set image contrast, hue, saturation and brightness

sect2.title: clone
sect2.para: Ce filtre vous permet de dupliquer l'image.

sect2.title: crop
sect2.para: This filter allows you to crop parts of the image.

sect2.title: motionblur
sect2.para: This filter adds a "motion blur" effect to the image.

sect1.title: Audio outputs
sect1.para: These modules allow you to choose the way the sound will be output to your audio system .

sect2.title: oss
sect2.para: This is the audio output for OSS (Open Sound System) output (/dev/dsp, for example, under Linux). It requires that your kernel was compiled with support for your sound card, or, if you use ALSA (Advanced Linux Sound System), the OSS emulation layer must be active.

sect2.title: alsa
sect2.para: This is the sound output for ALSA (Advanced Linux Sound Architecture). It only works under Linux, and it requires that you installed the ALSA drivers and libraries.

sect2.title: esd
sect2.para: This sound output has ESD (Enlightened Sound Daemon) support (usually used with Gnome). You must have the daemon and its libraries installed.

sect2.title: arts
sect2.para:
This sound output has aRts (KDE's sound server) support. You must have the daemon and its libraries installed
.

sect2.title: waveout
sect2.para: This is the Wave output, which is used by the win32 port.

sect2.title: coreaudio

para.emphasis: default: enabled on Mac OS X

sect2.para: This audio output uses CoreAudio under Mac OS X

sect2.title: sdl
sect2.para: This audio output uses SDL. Please refer to the video output.

sect1.title: Input modules
sect1.para: These modules allow VLC to read its streams from different sources .

sect2.title: dvdplay
sect2.para:
This is the regular DVD input module. It will need libdvdcss for DVD decryption (see the libdvdcss page) and libdvdplay for DVD navigation (see the libdvdplay page)
.

sect2.title: dvd
sect2.para:
This is the old DVD input module. It uses libdvdcss for DVD decryption (see the libdvdcss page)
.

sect2.title: dvdread
sect2.para: This is an alternative to the previous ones. It uses libdvdread for DVD reading (see the Ogle download page) and libdvdcss for DVD decryption (see the libdvdcss page).

sect2.title: vcd
sect2.para:
This is the VideoCD input
.

sect2.title: cdda
sect2.para:
This is the Audio CD input
.

sect2.title: http,ftp,udp,file,directory,mms
sect2.para:
These are standard input modules. The HTTP input can be used for Video On Demand
.

sect2.title: satellite
sect2.para:
This is an input module that allows to read directly from a Hauppauge WinTV Nova card under GNU/Linux. It requires drivers 0.9.4 available from linuxtv.org
.

sect2.title: v4l
sect2.para:
This module allows to get Video4Linux streams
.

sect2.title: dvb
sect2.para:
This module allows to read from DVB-S, DVB-T, and DBC-C satellite, digital terrestrial, or cable cards. It uses the Video4Linux 2 API, that is only available in kernel 2.5.X and 2.6.X
.

sect2.title: pvr
sect2.para: This module allows to read from Hauppauge PVR cards .

sect2.title: slp
sect2.para: This module allows to get the names and addresses for streams announced using the SLP protocol

sect1.title: Demuxers
sect1.para:
In a video stream, the video signal and the audio one are always into "containers" formats. Demuxers extract the streams from it and pass it to the decoders
.

For example, an AVI file can contain a MPEG-4 video, or an uncompressed video. AVI is only a storing format, not a compression format
.

sect2.title: avi
sect2.para:
This module allows you to read .avi files
.

sect2.title: asf
sect2.para: This module allows you to read .asf files

sect2.title: aac
sect2.para: This module allows you to read AAC files

sect2.title: ogg
sect2.para: This module allows you to read .ogg files

sect2.title: rawdv
sect2.para: This module allows you to read DV files

sect2.title: dvbpsi
sect2.para: This module allows to demux streams from a satellite card.

sect2.title: mp4
sect2.para: This module allows you to read .mp4 files

sect2.title: mkv
sect2.para:
This module allows you to read files that use the Matroska free format
.

sect2.title: ps,ts
sect2.para:
These modules allow you to read MPEG2 Program Stream or Transport Tream files
.

sect2.title: id3,m3u
sect2.para:
These modules allow you to read M3U, B4S, PLS, and ASX playlists, and ID3 tags
.

sect1.title: Interface modules
sect1.para: These modules allow you to choose the interface or interfaces you want to use (whether graphical or control interfaces).

sect2.title: wxwindows
sect2.para:
The wxWindows interface is a portable interface that is currently working under GNU/Linux and Windows. It is now the best graphical interface available under both Windows and GNU/Linux
.

sect2.title: skins
sect2.para:
This skinnable interface module works under Win32 and X11. You can create your own skins very easily with XML files
.

sect2.title: gtk
sect2.para:
This is the GTK+ interface. It needs gtk libraries and headers files if you are compiling it. Note that it can also be used under Windows
.

sect2.title: gnome
sect2.para:
This is the Gnome interface. It needs gnome libraries (libgnome32 package under Debian) and headers (libgnome-dev package under Debian) if you wish to compile it
.

sect2.title: qt
sect2.para:
This is the QT interface module. You will need the libraries (libqt2 package on Debian) and headers (libqt-dev package under Debian) if you wish to compile it
.

sect2.title: kde
sect2.para:
This is the KDE interface module. You will need the libraries (kdelibs3 package on Debian) and headers (kde-devel package under Debian) if you wish to compile it
.

sect2.title: rc
sect2.para:
This is the Remote Control interface module. It allows you to control VLC via commands, such as play, stop, etc... or via a script. This interface is text-based, so you should use it when you are in console mode
.

sect2.title: http
sect2.para:
This module allows you to remote control your VLC via a web browser. You can create custom web pages. More info here
.

sect2.title: ncurses
sect2.para:
This is a text interface, using ncurses library. You will need ncurses headers if you want to compile it (libncurses5-dev package on Debian)
.

sect2.title: lirc
sect2.para:
This interface module allows you to control VLC through a remote. A lircrc example is provided to help you configure it to your remote (see doc/lirc/example.lircrc)
.

sect2.title: opie
sect2.para:
This is an interface plugin for the Qt Embedded library (iPaq graphical library)
.

sect2.title: gestures
sect2.para:
This module allows you to control VLC via mouse gestures
.

sect2.title: joystick
sect2.para:
This module allows you to control VLC via a joystick with many options. More information can be found here
.

sect1.title: Codec modules
sect1.para:
The following modules add codec (ie, compression formats) support
.

sect2.title: a52
sect2.para:
This decoder uses liba52 (see the liba52 web site
.

sect2.title: ffmpeg
sect2.para:
This is a free MPEG-4/DivX/OpenDivX codec : ffmpeg (see the ffmpeg web site)
.

sect2.title: vorbis
sect2.para:
This codec allows you to read the Vorbis (audio) encoded files
.

sect2.title: xvid
sect2.para:
This codec allows you to read files encoded with Xvid (see Xvid web site)
.

sect2.title: mad
sect2.para:
This codec is a very smart MP3 decoder, that only uses integers. This allows its use for CPU which don't handle floating point numbers (on PDA, for example)
.

sect2.title: libmpeg2
sect2.para:
This codec allows to read MPEG2 files
.

sect2.title: faad
sect2.para:
Faad is an MPEG-4 audio decoder
.

sect2.title: tarkin
sect2.para:
tarkin is a new codec (experimental) by the Ogg Project (see the Ogg Vorbis web site)
.

sect2.title: theora
sect2.para:
theora is a new codec (experimental) by the Ogg Project (see the Ogg Vorbis web site)
.

sect2.title: cinepak
sect2.para:
This codec decodes the Cinepak format
.

sect2.title: tremor
sect2.para:
This is an Ogg/Vorbis codec that only makes integer calculus, which allow its use on CPU which don't have floating point support (see the Ogg Vorbis web
.

sect1.title: OS support modules
sect1.para:
The following modules add support for different OSs
.

sect2.title: macosx
sect2.para: This is the MacOS X support module, including a native interface .

sect2.title: qnx
sect2.para:
This is the QNX RTOS support module
.

sect1.title: Miscellaneous
sect1.para:
This section describes a few more modules that don't belong to any of the categories described before
.

sect2.title: sout
sect2.para:
Stream Output is a new feature of VLC that allows it to stream an MPEG-1, MPEG-2 or MPEG-4/DivX file or a DVD
.

For more details, please have a look at the section
.

sect2.title: test-suite
sect2.para: This builds a special VLC, for testing purposes only .

sect2.title: mozilla
sect2.para:
This is not really a module. When enabled, a VLC-based Mozilla plugin is built
.

sect2.title: xosd
sect2.para:
This plugin outputs the current stream to an "OSD" (On Screen Display)
.

sect1.title: Compilation Options
sect1.para:
There are a few options that you can set when running the configure script, which are not related to modules
.

You can have a look at these options by typing

You can for example control all the installation directories, the system for which you want to build VLC for (if not guessed correctly),...

sect2.title: --disable-plugins
sect2.para:
If you select this option, no plugins will be enabled. This is definitely not recommended, as you would get a very poor VLC, and should only be used for testing purposes

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:

sect1.title: Modules selection
sect1.para: VLC tries to select the most appropriate interface, input and output modules, among the ones available on the system, according to the stream it is given to read. However, you may wish to force the use of a specific module with the following options (for the complete list of modules, see the section) ) :

listitem.para:
--intf <module> allows you to select the interface module
.

--extraintf <module> allows you to select extra interface modules that will be launched in addition to the main one
.

--aout <module> allows you to select the audio output module
.

--vout <module> allows you to select the video output module
.

--filter <module> allows you to add a video filter module
.
--memcpy <module> allows you to choose a memory copy module .

sect2.title: Description of the stream output
sect2.para:
VLC's stream output allows VLC to be used as a streaming server instead of a client ! It has very extended capabilities
:

listitem.para:
stream in unicast and multicast on an IPv4 or IPv6 network everything that VLC is able to read, via UDP, RTP or HTTP
;

transcode an input stream, and then, send it, to the network or to a file
.

sect2.para:
To know about the full possibilities of VLC's stream output, see the streaming features page
.

sect2.title: Architecture and syntax
sect2.para:
the stream output has a powerful architecture that uses modules. Each module has capabilities, and you can chain the modules to enhance the possibilities
.

Here is the list of the modules currently available
:

listitem.para:
standard "sends" the stream via an access output module: for example, UDP, file, HTTP, ... You will probably want to use this module at the end of your chains
.

transcode
allows you to transcode the audio and the video of the input stream "on the fly" (if your computer is powerful enough)
.

duplicate allows you to create a second chain, where the stream will be handled in an independant way
.

display
allows you to display the input stream, as VLC would normally do. Used with the duplicate module, this allows you to view the stream as you send it
.

es allows you to make separate Elementary Etreams (ES) out of an input stream
.

sect2.para:
Each of these modules may take options. Here is the syntax that you must use
:

For example, to transcode a stream and send it, use
:

sect3.title: standard (alias std)
sect3.para:
Sends a stream
.
Options:

listitem.para: access: how to send : file, udp, rtp, http.

mux: which muxer (ie, which format) will be used. It can be one of
avi (for AVI format) , ogg (for OGG format) , ps (for MPEG2-PS format) , ts (for MPEG2-TS format)
.

url: if you use the file access, it will be the location where to store the stream; if you use another access, it will be the unicast or multicast IP address where you want to stream
.

sap: if you use the udp or rtp accesses, use this option to announce your stream, using SAP/SDP. This option contains the name under which you want to announce the program
.

slp: like sap, but use the SLP protocol. You need to have libslp on your system
.

sap_ipv: if you use the sap option, use this option to specify if you want to send the SAP announces in IPv4 or IPv6. The value of this option is 4 or 6 si vous utilisez sap, utilisez ceci pour spécifier si vous désirez envoyer les annonces SAP en IPv4 -défaut- ou IPv6. La valeur à utiliser est 4 ou 6 .

note.para: If you are streaming in multicast, you may want to use the global option --ttl 12 to set the TTL to a value superior to 1.

sect3.title: display
sect3.para:
Displays the stream
.
Options:

listitem.para:
noaudio: Ignore audio
.

novideo: Ignore video
.

sect3.title: duplicate
sect3.para:
Duplicates the stream to a new stream output chain
.
Options:

listitem.para:
dst: A new stream output chain of modules, as described earlier
.

sect3.title: transcode
sect3.para:
Changes the codec and/or bitrates for a stream
.
Options:

listitem.para: acodec: the new audio codec. It can be one of mpga (MPEG audio layer 2), a52 or ac3 (AC3 sound) or vorb (Vorbis)

ab: audio bitrate in Kbps
.

vcodec: the new video codec. It can be one of mp4v (MPEG4), mpgv (MPEG1), DIV1, DIV2, DIV3 (DivX 1,2,3), H263 (H263), I263 (H263I), WMV1 or WMV2 (Windows Media Video 1 or 2), MJPG (MJPEG), MJPB (MJPEGB)
.

width: video width
.

height: video height
.

vb: video bitrate in kbps
.

vt: video bitrate tolerance in bps
.

deinterlace: deinterlace the stream
.

croptop: number of pixels removed from the top of the video
.

cropbottom: number of pixel removed from the bottom of the video
.

cropleft: number of pixels removed from the left of the video
.

cropright: number of pixels removed from the right of the video
.

hq: high quality transcoding (uses more CPU)
.
qmin: minimum video quantiser scale (VBR)

qmax: maximum video quantiser scale (VBR)
.

sect3.title: es
sect3.para:
Make separate Elementary Streams
.
Options:

listitem.para:
access_audio: how to send the audio track: file, udp, rtp or http
.

access_video: how to send the vidéo track: file, udp, rtp or http
.

access: if you want the audio and the video tracks to use the same access, use this option instead of the two above
.

mux_audio: which muxer (ie, which format) will be used for the audio track. It can be one of avi (for AVI format), ogg (for OGG format), ps (for MPEG2-PS format), ts (for MPEG2-TS format)
.

mux_video: which muxer (ie, which format) will be used for the video track. It can be one of avi (for AVI format), ogg (for OGG format), ps (for MPEG2-PS format), ts (for MPEG2-TS format)
.

mux: if you want the audio and the video tracks to use the same muxer, use this option instead of the two above
.

url_audio: if you use the file access, it will be the location where to store the audio track; if you use another access, it will be the unicast or multicast IP address where you want to stream
.

url_video: if you use the file access, it will be the location where to store the vidéo track; if you use another access, it will be the unicast or multicast IP address where you want to stream
.

url: if you want the audio and the video tracks to use the same url, use this option instead of the two above
.

note.para: In the url options, if you use the file access, you can use the following macros in the filename:

listitem.para: %c = FOURCC ;
%a = access.

sect2.para:
To understand fully the complex syntax of VLC's stream output, please look at the use cases of the VideoLAN HOWTO

listitem.para:
--noaudio disables audio output
.

--mono forces VLC to treat the stream in mono audio
.

--volume <integer> sets the level of audio output
.

--aout-rate <integer> sets the audio output frequency (Hz)
.

--desync <integer> compensates desynchronization of audio (ms)
.
--headphone activates headphone virtual spatialization effect .

--headphone-dim sets headphone characteristic dimension
.

--novideo disables video output
.

--greyscale turns video output into greyscale mode
.

--fullscreen sets fullscreen video
.

--nooverlay disables hardware acceleration for the video output
.

--width, --height <integer> sets the video window dimensions
.

--zoom <float> adds a zoom factor
.
--aspect-ratio <mode> forces source aspect ratio .

--spumargin <integer> forces SPU subtitles postion
.

--playlist launches playlist on startup
.

--random plays files randomly forever
.

--enqueue enqueues items in playlist
.

--loop loops playlist on end
.

--server-port <integer> sets server port
.

--iface <string> specifies the network interface to use
.

--iface-addr <string> specifies your network interface IP address
.

--mtu <integer> specifies the MTU of the network interface
.

--ipv6 forces IPv6
.

--ipv4 forces IPv4
.

--nommx disables the use of MMX CPU extensions
.

--no3dn disables the use of 3D Now! CPU extensions
.

--nommxext disables the use of MMX Ext CPU extensions
.

--nosse disables the use of SSE CPU extensions
.

--quiet be quiet
.

--color displays color messages
.

--search-path <string> specifies interface default search path
.

--plugin-path <string> specifies plugin search path
.

--dvd <string> specifies the default VCD device
.

--vcd <string> specifies the default VCD device
.

--program <;integer> specifies program (SID) (for streams with several programs, like satellite ones)
.

--audio-type <integer> specifies the default audio type to use with dvds
.

--audio-channel <integer> specifies the default audio channel to use with dvds
.

--spu-channel <integer> specifies the default subtitle channel to use with dvds
.

--verbose <verbosity> specifies verbosity level
.

--help gives you all available options
.
--longhelp gives you a detailled version of the available options .

--version gives you information about the current VLC version
.

--list displays a list of available plugins
.

--module <module> displays help about specified module
.
